data.title: Time Tables Eerste and Tweede Divisie
data.text:
Netherlands - All-Time Tables Eerste and Tweede Divisie 1956-2015

In 1954 professional football was introduced in the Netherlands, and 1956/57 saw a national first division for the first time in history, called "eredivisie" (division of honour). As feeders, a second level league ("eerste divisie", consisting of two groups in the first few seasons) and a third level league ("tweede divisie", also consisting of two groups in the beginning) were added.

In general, all teams that went through name changes are listed under either their current name or (in case the club has disappeared from professional football) the last name under which they played professionally (so e.g. H.V.C. appear as S.C. Amersfoort, K.F.C. as F.C. Zaanstreek, 't Gooi as S.C. Gooiland, Fortuna Vlaardingen as F.C. Vlaardingen, and Zwartemeer as S.C. Drente). This in spite of the fact that clubs like H.V.C. and Fortuna Vlaardingen (or indeed T.O.P., who appear as F.C. Oss) never played in the tweede divisie under their more modern name. An exception is Xerxes, whose one-season merger with D.H.C. (when playing in the eredivisie) before disappearing from professional football is ignored below.

For teams that were formed by mergers, the records of the prime merger club (i.e. the club whose divisional place was taken by the merger club) have been added to those of the newly created club. (So, for instance, the record of Telstar includes that of V.S.V., whose place in the eerste divisie the merger club took in 1963, and not that of Stormvogels.) However, there are two exceptions to this:

D.W.S./A. was formed by a merger of D.W.S. and bvc Amsterdam, taking the eredivisie spot of bvc Amsterdam; the club later reverted to D.W.S. We therefore consider the merger club a continuation of D.W.S. rather than bvc Amsterdam. D.W.S. later merged (with Blauw Wit and later De Volewĳckers) into F.C. Amsterdam, which is (in accordance with the remark above) considered a continuation of D.W.S.

S.V.V./Dordrecht '90, the merger of S.V.V. and Dordrecht '90 (earlier known as D.F.C., F.C. Dordrecht and D.S. '79), took the eredivisie spot of S.V.V. but played in Dordrecht, and changed name to Dordrecht '90 (meanwhile F.C. Dordrecht) after just one season; because of this, we consider the merger club a continuation of the Dordrecht rather than the Schiedam club.

Oss 1 28 3 8 17 42 90 14 0,500 0,467 - 48 368 11276 4257 2762 4257 18500 18500 11274 -2 1 1 0 Explanations: S Seasons in tweede divisie (max. 15) Pd Matches played W Matches won D Matches drawn L Matches lost GF Goals scored GA Goals conceded Pts Number of points obtained (2/win) Ded Number of points deducted Pts/G Points per game ratio (based on 2/win) GAv Goal average GD Goal difference Note: playoff matches, championship deciders, and "nacompetitie" matches not included NB: for additional information on name changes, mergers, and the disappearance of clubs from Dutch professional football, see Netherlands - Regional Analysis. Trivia: Only Baronie and P.E.C. played in the tweede divisie in all 15 seasons of its existence; alone among all clubs which played 10 or more seasons at this level, Baronie had a positive record. Among current (2015) eredivisie clubs, P.E.C. Zwolle, S.C. Heerenveen, Roda J.C., De Graafschap and N.E.C. featured in the third level tweede divisie in more than half of the seasons it existed; P.E.C. Zwolle and S.C. Heerenveen had a negative record at this level.
